H0.text: Predator-prey is the type of relationship described when some wasp species lay their eggs inside living caterpillars, use the caterpillar as a food resource as the eggs mature, and ultimately have the wasp larvae hatch out of the caterpillar.

H1.text: Parasitic describes the relationship in which some wasp species lay their eggs inside living caterpillars, using the caterpillar as a food resource as the eggs mature, and eventually the wasp larvae hatch out of the caterpillar.

H2.text: Mutualistic is the type of relationship best described when some wasp species lay their eggs inside living caterpillars, use the caterpillar as a food resource as the eggs mature, and the wasp larvae hatch out of the caterpillar.

H3.text: Commensalistic is the best description of the relationship where some wasp species lay their eggs inside living caterpillars, use the caterpillar as a food resource as the eggs mature, and the wasp larvae eventually hatch out of the caterpillar.

A4.text: Koinobiont parasitoids lay their eggs inside young hosts, usually larvae. These are allowed to go on growing, so the host and parasitoid develop together for an extended period, ending when the parasitoids emerge as adults, leaving the prey dead, eaten from inside.

A5.text: Idiobiont parasitoids sting their often-large prey on capture, either killing them outright or paralysing them immediately. The immobilised prey is then carried to a nest, sometimes alongside other prey if it is not large enough to support a parasitoid throughout its development.
